awd_titl_txt: Selection and generation of limb movements by a combination of multifunctional and specialized spinal interneurons
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will address how nervous systems are organized to produce the right movement at the right time. It will focus on networks of nerve cells in the spinal cord since understanding these components is a prerequisite to understanding complex movements in animals and helping patients with spinal cord injuries. It will also train a broad range of undergraduates and graduate students to perform experiments. Finally, the award will also support hands-on activities for schoolchildren to spark their interest in science. 

Recent studies suggest that the spinal cord uses a combination of behaviorally specialized and multifunctional nerve cells (interneurons) to generate movements, but how it does so for limb movements is unknown. This project will study how specialized and multifunctional spinal interneurons contribute to producing two kinds of leg movements, swimming and scratching. The turtle is the only animal for which this is now feasible and is ideal for such studies because turtles, being diving animals, have evolved unusual resistance to low-oxygen conditions such as occur during many physiological experiments. The project will investigate the roles of one previously identified class of behaviorally specialized interneurons, scratch-specialized neurons, and one previously identified class of multifunctional interneurons, transverse interneurons. The project will determine whether each of these two classes of interneurons is excitatory or inhibitory, based on the neurotransmitter it uses, and whether it makes synaptic connections directly with motor neurons, using a combination of intracellular electrophysiology in vivo, dye injection, and immunocytochemistry.  The results of this study will reveal aspects of the organization of the spinal cord networks of neurons that generate different kinds of limb movements. The conclusions are likely to be broadly applicable to vertebrates, including humans, because the spinal cord is an evolutionarily conserved structure.

por.por_cntn:
The central nervous system generates the basic forms of many kinds of leg movements, including locomotion, through networks of nerve cells, called interneurons, that are contained entirely within the spinal cord, but how it does so is still not well understood. We previously found that the adult spinal cord uses a combination of multifunctional interneurons, which contribute to multiple kinds of leg movements, and behaviorally specialized interneurons, which are activated during one type of leg movement.

In the main experiments of this project, we investigated the outputs of these interneurons, which had not been done previously. We found that each functional category of interneurons includes some that are excitatory and others that are inhibitory, though most multifunctional interneurons were inhibitory. This, along with other previous evidence, suggests that inhibition plays a larger role than excitation in coordinating leg movements. We also found that both multifunctional and behaviorally specialized interneurons can have inputs directly onto motor neurons, through synaptic connections, and thereby directly affect muscle activation. We also found, surprisingly, that some motor neurons are behaviorally specialized and not activated during all kinds of leg movements.

In related projects supported by this award, we found that 1) stimuli that trigger two kinds of leg movements, swimming and scratching, are combined prior to motor neurons to generate a single, rhythmic output that is faster than either input triggers on its own; this suggests that these two kinds of rhythmic leg movements share a common network of spinal cord interneurons that generates the timing of movements; 2) a stimulus that triggers a leg withdrawal can interrupt and then restart an ongoing swimming rhythm, with new timing; this suggests that the limb withdrawal network and the swimming network share key elements; 3) some spinal cord interneurons send their outputs to two different locations, one of which is where knee-extensor motor neurons are and the other where hip-extensor motor neurons are; this suggests that the knee-hip synergy required for one form of scratching may be created by interneurons with such dual outputs; 4) a previously described kind of multi-second summation of skin sensory inputs, called windup, occurs not only for painful stimuli, as was well established, but also for skin touches that can barely be felt, and uses some of the same cellular mechanisms as windup of painful stimuli; this suggests that multi-second summation of skin sensory inputs may contribute to how we and other animals experience diverse kinds of skin stimuli.

Collectively, these findings help us understand better how the spinal cord coordinates different kinds of leg movements. Our findings are likely to apply to adult limbed vertebrates generally.

During this project, 15 undergraduates, including several women and an underrepresented minority, were trained to perform scientific research and to think like scientists. A postdoctoral fellow and two graduate students were also trained. Findings were published in several scientific journal articles. In addition, the Principal Investigator helped educate and engage non-scientists about how nervous systems work, in several ways: 1) leading Hands-on Brain Activities at 3-5 events/year, including state-wide events, involving > 1,000 children/year; 2) publishing a book for a general audience, Governing Behavior: How Nerve Cell Dictatorships and Democracies Control Everything We Do; 3) writing several online articles for a general audience for The Conversation; 4) writing blog posts for Psychology Today.
